Subject: RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?

------_=_NextPart_001_01C0B6DE.68DC31F0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"

Ok,
Here goes...
1. If you read back across the recent history of this -noloading phenom,
you'll see people who are having classloader issues are not confined to the
org.w3c class. This beast is popping up all over the place.
2. If someone wanted to masquerade as the poster child for reasons people
should avoid free software, you get the job. What is it about some of the
free-software folks out there who think that just because they churned out a
piece of code and shoved up onto a web page, that their software does not
have to be well designed, bug-free and taken just as seriously as a piece of
paid-for software?
3. I'm as grateful as the next bloke to Erick and Kent for JUnit. That said,
I'm hardly going to mute criticism where I feel that criticism is warranted.
Pointing this stuff out is how software gets better. If Erick and Kent are
as thin-skinned as you are, and I certainly hope they are not, they'll take
a gentle pointer to a bug trend in the spirit in which it is offered.
4. The point here is not the typical free-software red herring that usually
goes something like "how would you have done it better?". The point is to
fix something that is problematic and chronic. I'm sure if you take a deep
breath and eat a donut, even you can see the difference.

> -----Original Message-----
> From:	Dinwiddie, George [SMTP:George.Dinwiddie@...]
> Sent:	Tuesday, March 27, 2001 10:20 AM
> To:	'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject:	RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?
> 
> Yes, I still think your criticism is unwarranted.  
>  
> If org.w3c.dom.Document is calling the class loader itself, then problems
> are to be expected when a different class loader is used.  Is that what
> it's doing?  If I had the source I'd grep through it to see.
>  
> As Fergus noted, if you don't use JUnit's custom class loader, you have to
> restart the test application after each recompile.  This causes a
> significant slowdown in the edit-compile-test cycle.  Since the vast
> majority of applications don't have to play explicit games with the class
> loader, using the custom class loader for testing is a reasonable default.
> The default used to be to use the system class loader, but that was
> changed in version 3.3 and noted in the README file.  You're probably
> right that it should be noted in the FAQ, since it does seem to come up
> frequently.  Actually, looking at the FAQ, I notice the
> junit.util.excluded.properties noted there.  Perhaps this is another
> solution to the problem; you could run a test or check the source code.
>  
> My points are that Erich and Kent have done us all a big favor by
> releasing this code.  This code is still evolving; it's not surprising
> that the user documentation lags behind the capabilities, especially since
> the authors derive no remuneration for it.  However, the question about
> class loading problems has been answered as often as it's been asked, and
> the answers can be easily found both on sourceforge (
> <http://sourceforge.net/forum/message.php?msg_id=97007>) and here (I
> searched the archives for "loader constraints").  Searching the
> yahoogroups archive, I found the message
> <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/419> that verifies the
> excluded.properties solution works.
>  
> So, it seems to me that you're whinging about losing time for which your
> client is paying, and instead of thinking you should have determined the
> problem quicker or thinking that solving such problems is part of
> "delivering bullet-proof software," you're thinking that the authors of a
> free test package (that saves you time) have failed you.  I'm sorry to
> have to put it so bluntly, but you didn't get the hint in my previous
> message.  (BTW, if you check the JUnit zip file, you'll find test cases
> that indicate the authors DID test the program.)  As I see it, you're
> still looking a gift horse in the mouth and you still haven't answered the
> question, "how would you have done it better?"
>  
>  - George
> 
> 	-----Original Message-----
> 	From: Herrick, Chuck [mailto:chuck.herrick@...]
> 	Sent: Tuesday, March 27, 2001 9:44 AM
> 	To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> 	Subject: RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?
> 	
> 	
> 
> 	Did you not see this? I noticed it was missing from your reply: 
> 	-- 
> 	I even tried rebuilding my app from a full set of source files
> (including 
> 	dom source). 
> 
> 	The problem with the -noloading is that one can't rerun individual
> test 
> 	cases after a rebuild :-( 
> 
> 	Fergus 
> 	-- 
> 	The classloader issue comes up not just with the org.w3c object. I
> tripped across the -noloading botch myself, and wasted a good couple of
> hours trying to diagnose my problems with it.
> 
> 	This kind of thing provides great material to use to trip up folks
> during technical interviews, but is hardly conducive to the deliverance of
> bullet-proof software when your client is paying you by the hour.
> 
> 	Finally, I'd point out that someone shows up in this Yahoo.group
> having tripped over this JUnit classloader with a frequency of about 1 per
> week. Given that, do you really think my criticism is unwarranted?
> 
> 	-----Original Message----- 
> 	From:   Dinwiddie, George [SMTP:George.Dinwiddie@...] 
> 	Sent:   Tuesday, March 27, 2001 8:30 AM 
> 	To:     'junit@yahoogroups.com' 
> 	Subject:        RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner? 
> 
> 	Chuck, 
> 	  
> 	I think your criticism is unwarranted.  First of all, I find JUnit
> to be a wonderful help and I'm very glad to have it.  Second, the JUnit
> classloader DOES work.  I don't know what's going on within
> org.w3c.dom.Document, but in general, when the -noloading switch solves
> the problem it indicates that some part of the software is using a
> different class loader and that results in an object mismatch.  The
> response to this is to disable JUnit's reloading class loader and use the
> default one (which will not reload changed classes) that the software
> under test is expecting.  Is this a bad design decision?  Do you have a
> better solution to this problem?
> 
> 	  
> 	 - George 
> 
> 		-----Original Message-----
> 		From: Herrick, Chuck [ <mailto:chuck.herrick@...>]
> 		Sent: Tuesday, March 27, 2001 8:37 AM
> 		To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> 		Subject: RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?
> 		
> 		
> 
> 		Take a look at the security machinations that Java demands
> the classloader undergo on behalf of the virtual machine. 
> 
> 		I would say that if JUnit can't complete some very
> fundamental piece of its business because the authors made bad design
> decisions regarding the classloader, you'd need to get someone to go back
> and refactor JUnit.
> 
> 		Perhaps someone should have tested JUnit with some test
> software before rolling it out. 
> 
>

fundamental piece of its business because the authors made bad design decis=
ions regarding the classloader, you'd need to get someone to go back and re=
factor JUnit.</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=3D2 FACE=3D"Arial">Perhaps someone =
should have tested JUnit with some test software before rolling it out.</FO=
NT><FONT FACE=3D"Arial"> </FONT>
</P>
